question: Does genetic knockout of PKG-Iα in mice significantly alter the expression of pain hypersensitivity compared with wild-type controls? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Here, we found that Protein Kinase G1 (PKG-I) localized presynaptically in nociceptor terminals plays an essential role in the expression of spinal LTP.
content.source_2: In a cohort of adult Prkg1fl/fl;Advillin-Cre mice, nociceptor-specific deletion of PKG-Iα left capsaicin-evoked dorsal horn LTP intact and yielded mechanical and thermal hypersensitivity trajectories indistinguishable from littermate controls over 72 hours post-challenge.
content.source_3: Our results thus indicate that presynaptic mechanisms involving an increase in release probability from nociceptors are operational in the expression of synaptic LTP on spinal-PAG projection neurons and that PKG-I localized in presynaptic nociceptor terminals plays an essential role in this process to regulate pain sensitivity.
content.source_4: In female mice with neonatal Nav1.8-Cre–mediated ablation of PKG-I, presynaptic release probability and miniature EPSC frequency at nociceptor terminals were unchanged, spinal-PAG neuron LTP was preserved, and both inflammatory and neuropathic pain hypersensitivity developed to the same extent and time course as in controls.
